Travel Mode

Systems and mechanics for journeys and overland movement

When the party is moving between locations over significant distances, you're in Travel Mode. This mode abstracts moment-to-moment details to focus on the journey as a whole.

Core Systems for Travel

Movement & Travel

The primary system for this mode:

  • Travel Pace:
    • Fast (30 miles/day): -5 to passive Perception
    • Normal (24 miles/day): Standard movement
    • Slow (18 miles/day): Can use Stealth
  • Mounts & Vehicles: Faster travel speeds
  • Forced March: Travel beyond 8 hours requires CON saves

Exploration Activities

What you do while traveling:

  • Navigating: Wilderness Survival check to avoid getting lost
  • Drawing Maps: Recording your route
  • Foraging: Finding food (1d6 + WIS pounds on DC 15)
  • Tracking: Following another group
  • Keeping Watch: Staying alert during travel

Environmental Effects & Hazards

Challenges during travel:

  • Extreme Heat: CON save (DC 5 +1/hour) or gain Exhaustion
  • Extreme Cold: DC 10 CON save per hour or gain Exhaustion
  • Storms: Difficult terrain, navigation challenges
  • Getting Lost: Navigation failures lead to wasted time

Exhaustion & Resting

Recovery during journeys:

  • Forced March: CON save (DC 10 +1/hour) or gain Exhaustion
  • Long Rest: 8-hour rest to regain HP and reduce Exhaustion
  • Short Rest: 1-hour break to spend Hit Dice

Travel Activities by Role

  • Navigator: Makes Survival checks to avoid getting lost
  • Scout: Moves ahead to spot danger
  • Forager: Gathers food and water for the party
  • Lookout: Watches for threats

Transitioning Out of Travel Mode

Travel mode typically transitions to:

  • Exploration Mode: When arriving at a destination to investigate
  • Combat Mode: When ambushed or encountering hostile creatures
  • Interaction Mode: When arriving at settlements or meeting travelers
  • Downtime Mode: When spending extended time at a destination
